        5c
        Chirality measures of α-amino acids
        Jamroz, Michal H.; Rode, Joanna E.; Ostrowski, Slawomir; Lipinski, Piotr F. J.; Dobrowolski, Jan Cz.
        Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling (2012), 52 (6), 1462-1479CODEN: JCISD8; ISSN:1549-9596. (American Chemical Society)
        To measure mol. chirality, the mol. is treated as a finite set of points in the Euclidean R3 space supplemented by k properties, p1(i), p2(i), ..., pk(i) assigned to the ith atom, which constitute a point in the Property Pk space. Chirality measures are described as the distance between a mol. and its mirror image minimized over all its arbitrary orientation-preserving isometries in the R3 × Pk Cartesian product space. Following this formalism, different chirality measures can be estd. by taking into consideration different sets of at. properties. Here, for α-amino acid zwitterionic structures taken from the Cambridge Structural Database and for all 1684 neutral conformers of 19 biogenic α-amino acid mols., except glycine and cystine, found at the B3LYP/6-31G** level, chirality measures have been calcd. by a CHIMEA program written in this project. It is demonstrated that there is a significant correlation between the measures detd. for the α-amino acid zwitterions in crystals and the neutral forms in the gas phase. Performance of the studied chirality measures with changes of the basis set and computation method was also checked. An exemplary quant. structure-activity relationship (QSAR) application of the chirality measures was presented by an introductory model for the benchmark Cramer data set of steroidal ligands of the sex-hormone binding globulin.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XmvFWqs7Y%253D&md5=d0ed0e191a5619d6d6fd71893d062893
        (d) Elgavi, H.; Krekeler, C.; Berger, R.; Avnir, D. J. Phys. Chem. C 2012, 116, 330– 335
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5d
        Chirality in Copper Nanoalloy Clusters
        Elgavi, Hadassah; Krekeler, Christian; Berger, Robert; Avnir, David
        Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2012), 116 (1), 330-335CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
        It is shown that chirality is common in bimetallic clusters. Specifically, a detailed computational study of two copper clusters, Cun+ (n = 9,11), demonstrates that exchange of one copper atom with another metal atom (Ni, Zn, Ag, or Au) at various locations, leads, in most cases, to chirality in the a priori achiral cluster (n = 9) and always preserves it in the a priori chiral one (n = 11). Chirality was evaluated on a quant. level, employing the Continuous Chirality Measure methodol., in two versions: a purely geometric structure anal., and an anal. which takes into account the different nature of the atoms. Phys. aspects of chirality were demonstrated by emergence of vibrational CD signals and by the emergence of parity violation (PV) energy difference, which is calcd. by employing a quasi-relativistic approach. In the case of AgCu10+(p9), the PV energy splitting value is about ∼10-15 Hartree, bringing this nanoalloy close to the range of systems that have been discussed as promising candidates for a measurement of this phenomenon on the mol. level.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsFKgsr7I&md5=e5d6b299327b1d2998b1f87df7694fe0
      6. 6
        (a) Wernsdorfer, W.; Aliaga-Alcalde, N.; Hendrickson, D. N.; Christou, G. Nature 2002, 416, 406– 409
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6a
        Exchange-biased quantum tunnelling in a supramolecular dimer of single-molecule magnets
        Wernsdorfer Wolfgang; Aliaga-Alcalde Nuria; Hendrickson David N; Christou George
        Nature (2002), 416 (6879), 406-9 ISSN:0028-0836.
        Various present and future specialized applications of magnets require monodisperse, small magnetic particles, and the discovery of molecules that can function as nanoscale magnets was an important development in this regard. These molecules act as single-domain magnetic particles that, below their blocking temperature, exhibit magnetization hysteresis, a classical property of macroscopic magnets. Such 'single-molecule magnets' (SMMs) straddle the interface between classical and quantum mechanical behaviour because they also display quantum tunnelling of magnetization and quantum phase interference. Quantum tunnelling of magnetization can be advantageous for some potential applications of SMMs, for example, in providing the quantum superposition of states required for quantum computing. However, it is a disadvantage in other applications, such as information storage, where it would lead to information loss. Thus it is important to both understand and control the quantum properties of SMMs. Here we report a supramolecular SMM dimer in which antiferromagnetic coupling between the two components results in quantum behaviour different from that of the individual SMMs. Our experimental observations and theoretical analysis suggest a means of tuning the quantum tunnelling of magnetization in SMMs. This system may also prove useful for studying quantum tunnelling of relevance to mesoscopic antiferromagnets.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD387ovVSqsg%253D%253D&md5=6c9c50afd923a966e63fd251d5edffc6
        (b) Wang, X. Y.; Wang, Z. M.; Gao, S. Chem. Commun. 2008, 281– 294
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6b
        Constructing magnetic molecular solids by employing three-atom ligands as bridges
        Wang, Xin-Yi; Wang, Zhe-Ming; Gao, Song
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2008), (3), 281-294CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The combination of some three-atom bridges with paramagnetic 3d transition metal ions results in the systematic isolation of mol. magnetic materials, ranging from single-mol. and single-chain magnets to layered weak ferromagnets and three-dimensional porous magnets. The design strategy and role of secondary components, such as co-ligands, templates and other mixed short ligands are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXit1GnsQ%253D%253D&md5=43e0a487ce764435e4f58944777e85ef

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6c
        Azido-mediated systems showing different magnetic behaviors
        Zeng, Yong-Fei; Hu, Xin; Liu, Fu-Chen; Bu, Xian-He
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (2), 469-480CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Azido has been one of the well used bridging ligands in the construction of magnetic mol. materials, which has stimulated considerable interest in magnetochem. This tutorial review is concd. on the study of azido metal compds. with their magnetochem. and consists of eight main sections. The first section offers an introduction to azido complexes and some important results obtained from magneto-structural correlation in azido complexes which will be referred to in the following sections. The next six sections give overviews of azido-mediated ferromagnets, ferrimagnets, canted (weak) ferromagnets, antiferromagnets, single mol. magnets (SMMs) and single chain magnets (SCMs), and metamagnets. The last section is the conclusion and gives a perspective of azido-mediated magnets.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6d
        CoII Molecular Square with Single-Molecule Magnet Properties
        Wu, Dayu; Guo, Dong; Song, You; Huang, Wei; Duan, Chunying; Meng, Qingjin; Sato, Osamu
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2009), 48 (3), 854-860CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new tetranuclear cobalt(II) mol. square in which adjacent CoII centers are linked by a μ2-bridging oxygen atom and a N-N bridge along the edges of the square was designed for single-mol. magnets (SMMs) with high anisotropy barriers. The overall intramol. ferromagnetic coupling at low temp. combined with the slow relaxation at static zero fields suggests a SMM behavior for this mol. square. The zero-field cooled magnetization (ZFCM) and field cooling magnetization (FCM) at 10 Oe illustrate the nonreversibility and bifurcation <4.5 K. The deviations of magnetization from the satd. value in strong applied fields demonstrate the participation of low-lying excited states. The peaks of the out-of-phase signals are obsd. corresponding to coincidence of the applied a.c. field oscillation frequency with the relaxation rate.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXjtVeqtA%253D%253D&md5=4b552fd71dd43a7f9b2768cafefb4b4e
        (e) Bhargavi, G.; Rajasekharan, M. V.; Costes, J.; Tuchagues, J. Polyhedron 2009, 28, 1253– 1260
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6e
        Synthesis, crystal structure and magnetic properties of dimeric MnIII Schiff base complexes including pseudohalide ligands: Ferromagnetic interactions through phenoxo bridges and single molecule magnetism
        Bhargavi, G.; Rajasekharan, M. V.; Costes, J.-P.; Tuchagues, J.-P.
        Polyhedron (2009), 28 (7), 1253-1260CODEN: PLYHDE; ISSN:0277-5387. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Three new phenoxo-bridged dimeric compds. of MnIII with tetradentate Schiff bases (salpnH2, salmenH2 and acphpnH2) and pseudohalide ligands were synthesized and characterized by crystallog. and d.c. and a.c. magnetic measurements. Mn(salpn)NCO (1) and Mn(salmen)N3 (2) exhibit intra-dimer ferromagnetic exchange (J = 0.42(2) cm-1 for 1, J = 0.58(1) cm-1 for 2, H = - 2JS1S2). The χmT product of 1 continuously increases upon lowering temp., reaching a value of 10.01 cm3mol-1K at 1.98 K. In the case of 2, the χmT product reaches a max. value of 7.85 cm3mol-1K at 5.82 K and decreases upon further cooling to a value of 6.34 cm3mol-1K at 2 K, indicating the operation of inter-dimer antiferromagnetic interactions. Frequency dependence of a.c. magnetic susceptibility shows single-mol.-magnetic (SMM) behavior in the temp. range 2-10 K for both compds. In sharp contrast, Mn(acphpn)N3 exhibits antiferromagnetic exchange interactions. salpnH2 = N,N'-bis(salicylidene)-1,3-diaminopropane, salmenH2 = N,N'-bis(salicylidene)-1,2-diaminopropane and acphpnH2 = N,N'-bis(2-hydroxyacetophenone)-1,3-diaminopropane.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkslKqsb8%253D&md5=d9276803a2c37d12bf004f1537fde0b6
      7. 7
        (a) Seo, J. S.; Whang, D.; Lee, H.; Jun, S. I.; Oh, J.; Jeon, Y. J.; Kim, K. Nature 2000, 404, 982– 986
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7a
        A homochiral metal-organic porous material for enantioselective separation and catalysis
        Seo, Jung Soo; Whang, Dongmok; Lee, Hyoyoung; Jun, Sung Im; Oh, Jinho; Jeon, Young Jin; Kim, Kimoon
        Nature (London) (2000), 404 (6781), 982-986CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A homochiral metal-org. porous material with a carboxylic group at one end and a pyridyl group at the other forming oxo-bridged trinuclear metal carboxylate units in a three-dimensional framework was prepd., that allows enantioselective inclusion of metal complexes in its pores and catalyzes transesterification reactions in an enantioselective manner. The enantiopure chiral building block was prepd. from D-tartaric acid and 4-aminopyridine; then reaction with Zn2+ produced a homochiral open-framework solid, D-POST-1. The enantiomorphic L-POST-1 was obtained from the enantiomer of the building block and Zn2+ under the same conditions. The pyridyl groups in POST-1 can be converted to N-methylpyridinium without any changes of the network structure; the anion can be reversibly exchanged with other anions, e.g., PF6-, I3-, p-toluenesulfonate, etc. The pore size of POST-1 materials is modulated by N-alkylation and is dependent on alkyl chain length. The pyridyl groups are responsible for the catalytic activity of the oxo-bridged trinuclear metal complexes, in e.g., transesterification of 2,4-dinitrophenyl acetate (NPA) with ethanol, which produced Et acetate in 77% yield, only in the presence of POST-1. Transesterification with bulkier alcs. occurs more slowly or not at all, suggesting that catalysis occurs mainly in the POST-1 channels. The catalytic activity of D- and L-POST-1 is enantioselective as obsd. in the transesterification of NPA with 1-phenyl-2-propanol, which produces the corresponding esters with about 88% enantiomeric excess in favor of the resp. enantiomer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXjtFyns7k%253D&md5=2ec5611e7804e3cf7bc738334b415470
        (b) Horike, S.; Dincă, M.; Tamaki, K.; Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 5854– 5855
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7b
        Size-Selective Lewis Acid Catalysis in a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework with Exposed Mn2+ Coordination Sites
        Horike, Satoshi; Dinca, Mircea; Tamaki, Kentaro; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (18), 5854-5855CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Treatment of selected aldehydes and ketones R1COR2 (R1 = Ph, R2 = H, Me; R1 = 4-PhC6H4, 4-PhOC6H4, 1-naphthyl, R2 = H) with Me3SiCN in the presence of the microporous metal-org. framework Mn3[(Mn4Cl)3BTT8(CH3OH)10]2 (I, H3BTT = 1,3,5-benzenetristetrazol-5-yl) leads to rapid conversion to the corresponding cyanosilylated products R1R2C(CN)OSiMe3. The transformation is catalyzed by coordinatively unsatd. Mn2+ ions that serve as Lewis acids and lead to conversion yields of 98 and 90% for benzaldehyde and 1-naphthaldehyde, the highest thus far for a metal-org. framework. Larger carbonyl substrates cannot diffuse through the pores of I, and conversion yields are much lower for these, attesting to the heterogeneity of the reaction and its dependence on guest size. The Mukaiyama-aldol reaction, known to require much more active Lewis catalysts, is also catalyzed in the presence of I, representing the first such example for a metal-org. framework. Conversion yields obtained for the reaction of benzaldehyde with silyl enolate Me2C:C(OMe)OSiMe3 reach 63%, on par with those obtained with zeolites. Size selectivity is demonstrated for the first time with this reaction through the use of larger silyl enolate substrates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXksVeqs7w%253D&md5=4c04e2441b790417d12ba4fa084d9c10
        (c) Lee, J.; Farha, O. K.; Roberts, J.; Scheidt, K. A.; Nguyen, S. T.; Hupp, J. T. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1450– 1459
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7c
        Metal-organic framework materials as catalysts
        Lee, Jeong Yong; Farha, Omar K.; Roberts, John; Scheidt, Karl A.; Nguyen, Son Binh T.; Hupp, Joseph T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1450-1459CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review; a crit. review of the emerging field of MOF-based catalysis is presented. Discussed are examples of: (a) opportunistic catalysis with metal nodes, (b) designed catalysis with framework nodes, (c) catalysis by homogeneous catalysts incorporated as framework struts, (d) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated mol. species, (e) catalysis by metal-free org. struts or cavity modifiers, and (f) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated clusters.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Probing the Lewis Acid Sites and CO Catalytic Oxidation Activity of the Porous Metal-Organic Polymer [Cu(5-methylisophthalate)]

        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (27), 8402-8403CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A new metal-org. polymer material exhibits the excellent and stable CO oxidn. catalytic activity. Its open Lewis acid sites on the channel walls were probed by CO adsorption.

        7e
        Direct Crystallographic Observation of Catalytic Reactions inside the Pores of a Flexible Coordination Polymer
        Das, Raj Kumar; Aijaz, Arshad; Sharma, Manish K.; Lama, Prem; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (22), 6866-6872CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new flexible porous coordination polymer (PCP), {[Gd2(L)3(DMF)4]·4DMF·3H2O}n (1), was synthesized under solvothermal condition by reacting [Gd(NO3)3]·6H2O with the ligand 2,6,2',6'-tetranitro-biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2L). Compd. 1 had a 3-dimensional coordination polymeric structure with two types of 1-dimensional channels (A and B) that were occupied by DMF and H2O mols. When crystals of 1 were sep. exposed to vapors of various arom. aldehydes, either the lattice or both the lattice and metal-bound solvent mols. were replaced by aldehyde mols. The aldehyde mols. inside the pores spontaneously underwent cyanosilylation and Knoevenagel condensation reactions upon exposure to vapors of trimethylsilyl cyanide and malononitrile, resp. These reactions took place at ambient temp. and pressure. Also, both the reactants and the products translocated from one cavity to another. The products that occupied the cavity were expunged upon exposure to the vapors of an aldehyde. Because crystallinity was maintained during these chem. transformations, direct crystallog. observation was possible. Herein, confinement of the reactants inside the void spaces of the PCP led to the products; the authors also assessed catalytic activities of this PCP in bulk quantities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XlvVKmur4%253D&md5=8c162c69892e6ad73d5531ca5de5d2b0

        (a) Zou, R.-Q.; Zhong, R.-Q.; Du, M.; Pandey, D. S.; Xu, Q. Cryst. Growth Des. 2008, 8, 452– 459
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8a
        Controllable Congregating of Homochiral and Achiral Coordination Polymers: Cadmium(II) Pyridine-2,4,6-Tricarboxylate Species with Double-Helical Strand and Molecular Building Block Structures
        Zou, Ru-Qiang; Zhong, Rui-Qin; Du, Miao; Pandey, Daya S.; Xu, Qiang
        Crystal Growth & Design (2008), 8 (2), 452-459CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Three kinds of three-dimensional (3D) Cd(II) pyridine-2,4,6-tricarboxylate (L) coordination polymers, L-[Cd(L)](NH2Me2) (1a), R-[Cd(L)](NH2Me2) (1b), [Cd3(L)2(H2O)4] (2), and [Cd4(L)2(OH)2(H2O)3](H2O) (3), were hydro/solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. The variations of reaction medium and temp. not only led to an occurrence of spontaneous chiral resoln. but also afforded two achrial mol. building block structures. Complexes 1a and 1b crystallize in trigonal P3121 and P3221 space groups with homochiral left- and right-handed double-helical strand arrays, while 2 and 3 self-assemble into two kinds of achiral coordination polymers with mol. building block structures. Complexes 2 and 3 remain intact after removal of the coordinated H2O mols., which indicates that their dehydrated frameworks possess guest-free metal coordination sites. Complexes 1-3 also display strong fluorescent emissions at 638, 594, and 604 nm in the solid state.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Dinuclear and polynuclear lanthanide coordination complexes containing polyazine ligands: Synthesis and luminescent properties
        Swavey, Shawn; Swavey, Rochael
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2009), 253 (21-22), 2627-2638CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. The role of homodinuclear and heterodinuclear lanthanide complexes as building blocks for polymeric materials is a significant field of study in recent years. Accessing the desired luminescent properties of lanthanides in the most efficient and practical way is an important part of designing such complex structures. This review describes the background of the photophys. properties of a select no. of lanthanide ions. The synthesis and photophys. properties of dinuclear lanthanides were split into two sections: (I) heterodinuclear d-f complexes and (II) homodinuclear lanthanides bridged by polyazine ligands. A section on polymeric lanthanide arrays is also included highlighting d-f polymeric structures and a section on homodinuclear polymeric arrays formed from polyazine bridging ligands.

        (c) Du, M.; Jiang, X. J.; Zhao, X. J. Inorg. Chem. 2007, 46, 3984– 3995
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8c
        Molecular Tectonics of Mixed-Ligand Metal-Organic Frameworks: Positional Isomeric Effect, Metal-Directed Assembly, and Structural Diversification
        Du, Miao; Jiang, Xiu-Juan; Zhao, Xiao-Jun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (10), 3984-3995CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Nine mixed-ligand metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) were prepd. by the combination of a bent dipyridyl linker 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) and three benzenedicarboxylate isomers (pa = phthalate, i.p. = isophthalate, and tp = terephthalate), resp., with different metal ions such as CoII, NiII, CuII, ZnII, and CdII. The framework structures of these neutral polymeric complexes were detd. by the x-ray single-crystal diffraction technique. Structural anal. reveals that the benzenedicarboxylate isomers display versatile coordination modes to manage the metal ions to form 1-dimensional chain or ribbon arrays, which are further extended via the exo-bidentate bpt connectors to give rise to a variety of coordination networks, such as a simple (4,4) layer, 2-dimensional double layer with decorated (4,4) topol., 2-dimensional layer with decorated (3,6) topol., 2-dimensional bilayer with 82.10 topol. (2-fold interpenetration), 3-dimensional polythreaded architecture (1-dimensional + 2-D), and 2-fold interpenetrating porous lattice of (4,4) layers. The accessorial secondary interactions such as H bonding and/or arom. stacking are also helpful for the extension and stabilization of the final supramol. aggregates. This work evidently indicates that the isomeric effect of the anionic benzenedicarboxylate is significant in the construction of these network structures, which are also well regulated by the metal centers. The ZnII and CdII MOFs exhibit strong solid-state luminescence emissions at room temp., which originate differently from intraligand transition or ligand-to-metal charge transfer. Thermal stability of these cryst. materials was explored by TGA of mass loss. The 3-dimensional host frameworks of MOFs 8 and 9 show similar porous cavities, and their desorption/adsorption behaviors of guest solvents also were studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXkt1Sitrs%253D&md5=f09b4829061cefe846889e4813916bd4
        (d) Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhakta, R. K.; Houk, R. J. T. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1330– 1352
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8d
        Luminescent metal-organic frameworks
        Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhakta, R. K.; Houk, R. J. T.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1330-1352CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review; metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) display a wide range of luminescent behaviors resulting from the multifaceted nature of their structure. In this crit. review we discuss the origins of MOF luminosity, which include the linker, the coordinated metal ions, antenna effects, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest mols. The literature describing these effects is comprehensively surveyed, including a categorization of each report according to the type of luminescence obsd. Finally, we discuss potential applications of luminescent MOFs. This review will be of interest to researchers and synthetic chemists attempting to design luminescent MOFs, and those engaged in the extension of MOFs to applications such as chem., biol., and radiation detection, medical imaging, and electro-optical devices.

        9b
        Polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chemistry
        Carlucci, Lucia; Ciani, Gianfranco; Proserpio, Davide M.
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 247-289CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review is presented on polycatenation, polythreading and polyknotting in coordination network chem. The use of crystal engineering concepts produced a variety of coordination networks, many of which exhibit novel and fascinating types of entanglements of individual motifs. This review analyses the structures of a no. of entangled polymeric networks reported in these years by many groups. A topol. classification of the different interlocked and interweaved species is attempted. Wide classes of polycatenated and polythreaded species were recognized and other phenomena, as polyknotting (self-penetration) and interweaving of 1-dimensional chains, are also discussed. Unexpected topol. features and new linkages, that were previously overviewed, were discovered, including the first examples of infinite Borromean links.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Design and construction of self-penetrating coordination frameworks
        Ke, Xi-Jun; Li, Dong-Sheng; Miao Du
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2011), 14 (5), 788-803CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A review. Self-penetrating coordination networks have recently been demonstrated as an important family of coordination polymers with new topologies and properties. However, the design and control of self-penetrating systems is still an enthralling challenge. In this review, we present the topol. types of self-penetrating coordination networks, mainly with single-connectivity, and summarize their designing and constructing strategy.

        Protonated 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole templated luminescent lanthanide isophthalates with a rare (3,6)-connected topology
        Yin, Pei-xiu; Li, Zhao-ji; Zhang, Jian; Zhang, Lei; Lin, Qi-pu; Qin, Ye-yan; Yao, Yuan-gen
        CrystEngComm (2009), 11 (12), 2734-2738CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Although 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (AmTAZ) is often used as a ligand, its templating behavior has never been explored. Presented here are isomorphous lanthanide isophthalates, [Ln(i.p.)2(H2O)]·(HAmTAZ) (Ln = La (1), Sm (2), Tb (3); i.p. = isophthalate, AmTAZ = 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole), templated by protonated HAmTAZ+ cations. The three-dimensional (3D) anionic [Ln(i.p.)2(H2O)]n framework based on rod-like [Ln(COO)4(H2O)]n secondary building units (SBUs) exhibits rare (3,6)-connected (42.6)2(44.62.87.102) topol., and the guest HAmTAZ+ cations are trapped in the channels. Both compds. 2 and 3 show interesting luminescence properties.

        9f
        Porous Phosphorescent Coordination Polymers for Oxygen Sensing
        Xie, Zhigang; Ma, Liqing; de Krafft, Kathryn E.; Jin, Athena; Lin, Wenbin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (3), 922-923CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Phosphorescent cyclometalated iridium tris(2-phenylpyridine) derivs. were designed and incorporated into coordination polymers as tricarboxylate bridging ligands. Three different cryst. coordination polymers were synthesized using a solvothermal technique and were characterized using a variety of methods, including single-crystal x-ray diffraction, PXRD, TGA, IR spectroscopy, gas adsorption measurements, and luminescence measurements. The coordination polymer built from Ir[3-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 1, is highly porous with a nitrogen BET surface area of 764 m2/g, whereas the coordination polymers built from Ir[4-(2-pyridyl)benzoate]3, 2 and 3, were nonporous. The 3MLCT phosphorescence of each of the three coordination polymers was quenched in the presence of O2. However, only 1 showed quick and reversible luminescence quenching by oxygen, whereas 2 and 3 exhibited gradual and irreversible luminescence quenching by oxygen. The high permanent porosity of 1 allows for rapid diffusion of oxygen through the open channels, leading to efficient and reversible quenching of the 3MLCT phosphorescence. This work highlights the opportunity of designing highly porous and luminescent coordination polymers for sensing other important analytes.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1alurrL&md5=5b4db906f93aa4289f08b1946f61662e
        (g) Zheng, B.; Bai, J.; Duan, J.; Wojtas, L.; Zaworotko, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2011, 133, 748– 745
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Enhanced CO2 binding affinity of a high-uptake rht-type metal-organic framework decorated with acylamide groups
        Zheng, Baishu; Bai, Junfeng; Duan, Jingui; Wojtas, Lukasz; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (4), 748-751CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        An rht-type metal-org. framework (MOF) prepd. from M2(carboxylate)4 (M = Cu, Co) paddlewheel clusters and a flexible C3-sym. hexacarboxylate ligand with acylamide groups exhibits larger CO2 uptake, an enhanced heat of adsorption, and higher selectivity toward CO2/N2 in comparison with what was previously obsd. for an analogous MOF with alkyne groups.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsF2ku77O&md5=d6d344c487e474f8969de5720df246c8

        9h
        pH Influence on the Structural Variations of 4,4'-Oxydiphthalate Coordination Polymers
        Yang, Jin-Xia; Zhang, Xin; Cheng, Jian-Kai; Zhang, Jian; Yao, Yuan-Gen
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (1), 333-345CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new Zn(II)/ODPT/bpe compds., namely, {[Zn(bpe)(H2O)2](H2ODPT)·3H2O}n (1), {[Zn4(ODPT)2(bpe)3(H2O)2]2(bpe)·7H2O}n (2), {[Zn2(ODPT)(bpe)2]2·7H2O}n (3), {Zn4(ODPT)2(bpe)}n (4), and {Zn2(ODPT)(bpe)(H2O)2}n (5) (ODPT = 4,4'-oxydiphthalate, bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane), have been synthesized through a hydrothermal method under different pH conditions, and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, element anal., IR spectra (IR), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. Compd. 1 shows a 3D network framework constructed by the 1D linear [Zn(bpe)(H2O)4]n2+ cationic chains through extensive hydrogen-bonding. Compd. 2 displays an unusual three-dimensional (3D) meso-racemic self-penetrating coordination network with distinct chiral information in the interpenetrating networks. Compd. 3 features a novel 4-connected (4·62·83)(42·62·82) topol., also exhibiting an intriguing 3D self-penetrating structure formed by triple- and double-stranded helical chain motifs. Compds. 4 and 5 are based upon 3D pillared-layer frameworks constructed from Zn2+ and ODPT4-, and further consolidated by the bpe ligands as mol. pillars. The most striking feature of 5 is that achiral ODPT4- ligands link the Zn cations into right-handed 21 helical chains, and the chiral information is transferred to the 3D framework with a chiral space group C2221. The diversity of the product structures illustrates the marked sensitivity of the coordination chem. of the V-shaped multicarboxylate ligand (H4ODPT) to the pH value of the soln. Moreover, the thermal dynamic properties and fluorescent properties of all compds. were also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhsVKiu77L&md5=2782676a041a3403a3fb720eab621537

        (a) Pan, L.; Sander, M. B.; Huang, X.; Li, J.; Smith, M.; Bittner, E.; Bockrath, B.; Johnson, J. K. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 1308– 1309

        10a
        Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
        Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. New materials with significantly improved H adsorption capability are needed. Microporous metal coordination materials (MMOMs) are promising sorbents for H adsorption. These materials possess phys. characteristics similar to those of single-walled C nanotubes and they also have a no. of advantages. A novel MMOM structure and its room-temp. H adsorption properties are presented.

        10b
        Directed assembly and reactivity of olefins within a one-dimensional ladder-like coordination polymer based on a dinuclear Zn(II) platform
        Papaefstathiou, Giannis S.; Georgiev, Ivan G.; Friscic, Tomislav; MacGillivray, Leonard R.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2005), (31), 3974-3976CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A ladder-like coordination polymer, [Zn(L)(OH)(4,4'-bpe)2](ClO4)2·4H2O (HL = 2,6-bis[N-(2-pyridylethyl)formimidoyl]-4-methylphenol, 4,4'-bpe = trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene) involving a dinuclear Zinc Schiff-base complex possesses org. linkers was prepd. and its crystal structure detd. This complex undergoes a [2 + 2] photodimerization in the solid state.

        10c
        A 3D Canted Antiferromagnetic Porous Metal-Organic Framework with Anatase Topology through Assembly of an Analogue of Polyoxometalate
        Xiang, Shengchang; Wu, Xintao; Zhang, Jianjun; Fu, Ruibiao; Hu, Shengmin; Zhang, Xudong
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (47), 16352-16353CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The unique porous metal-org. framework {KCo3(C6H4O7)(C6H5O7)(H2O)2·8H2O}8 (1), which exhibits an unprecedented infinite 3-dimensional (3,6)-connected decorated anatase net, was obtained by hydrothermal reaction. Upon dehydration, the compd. retains crystallinity and exhibits a type I N2 sorption isotherm, characteristic of a microporous solid with apparent Langmuir surface area 939 m2/g and pore vol. 0.31 cm3/g. Magnetic measurements for both 1 and dehydrated 1 show the spin-canted antiferromagnetic state <5 K and a magnetic hysteresis loop at 2 K. Thus, dehydrated 1 represents the 1st metal-org. framework for which microporosity and a spin-canted antiferromagnetic state coexist, which demonstrates that the self-assembly of organo-polymetal clusters and metal ions can provide a potential route to magnetic porous metal-org. frameworks.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Chiral Polyoxometalate-Induced Enantiomerically 3D Architectures: A New Route for Synthesis of High-Dimensional Chiral Compounds
        Tan, Huaqiao; Li, Yangguang; Zhang, Zhiming; Qin, Chao; Wang, Xinlong; Wang, Enbo; Su, Zhongmin
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (33), 10066-10067CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two new enantiomerically chiral 3-dimensional architectures, L-(Zn(H2O)3)3[MnMo9O32]·4H2O and D-(Zn(H2O)3)3[MnMo9O32]·4H2O, were produced from a new way. The compds. were composed of the discrete chiral [MnMo9O32]6- polyoxoanions linked by Zn(II) atoms to a 3-dimensional framework with a 2-fold interpenetrating net, which is the 1st examples of POM-based chiral 3-dimensional frameworks consisting of only inorg. components.

        Two Novel Copper-Undecaniobates Decorated by Copper-Organic Cations [{Cu(H2O)L}2{CuNb11O35H4}]5- (L = 1,10-phenanthroline, 2,2'-bipyridine) Consisting of Plenary and Monolacunary Lindqvist-Type Isopolyniobate Fragments
        Niu, Jing-Yang; Chen, Guo; Zhao, Jun-Wei; Ma, Peng-Tao; Li, Su-Zhi; Wang, Jing-Ping; Li, Ming-Xue; Bai, Yan; Ji, Bian-Sheng
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2010), 16 (24), 7082-7086, S7082/1-S7082/17CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Introducing arom. amine ligands (1,10-phenanthroline = phen, 2,2'-bipyridine = 2,2'-bipy) and Cu2+ ion into the [Nb6O19]8- system to construct org.-inorg. hybrid PONs, the authors have obtained two hybrid Cu-undecaniobates K3Na2[{Cu(H2O)(phen)}2(CuNb11O35H4)]·22H2O (1) and K4Na[{Cu(H2O)(2,2'-bipy)}2(CuNbuO35H4)]·25H2O (2), each contg. a novel [CuNb11O35H4]9- (CuNb11) cluster consisting of plenary and monolacunary Lindqvist-type isopolyniobate fragments, which also demonstrate impressive antitumor activities along with aq. soln. soly. and stability. The x-ray crystal structure, photoelec. properties, MLCT and cyclic voltammetry are also reported.

        10g
        Solvothermal assembly of a series of organic-inorganic hybrid materials constructed from Keggin polyoxometalate clusters and copper(I)-organic frameworks
        Liu, Hai-Yan; Wu, Hua; Yang, Jin; Liu, Ying-Ying; Ma, Jian-Fang; Bai, Hong-Ye
        Crystal Growth & Design (2011), 11 (5), 1786-1797CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Seven polyoxometalate (POM) hybrid materials based on Keggin polyanion building blocks and copper(I)-org. frameworks with pyrazine derivs., namely, [CuI4(2Et,3Me-Pyr)5(SiW12O40)] (1), [CuI4(2,6-Pyr)4(SiW12O40)] (2), [CuI4(2,5-Pyr)4(SiW12O40)(H2O)2] (3), [CuI4(2,3,5,6-Pyr)4(SiW12O40)](H2O) (4), [CuI4(2,5-Pyr)4(PMo11VIMoVO40)]·1.5H2O (5), [CuI3(2,3,5-Pyr)4(PMo12O40)]·H2O (6), and [CuI4(2Et,3Me-Pyr)5(PMo11VIMoVO40)] (7), where 2Et,3Me-Pyr = 2-ethyl-3-methylpyrazine, 2,6-Pyr = 2,6-dimethylpyrazine, 2,5-Pyr = 2,5-dimethylpyrazine, 2,3,5-Pyr = 2,3,5-trimethylpyrazine, and 2,3,5,6-Pyr = 2,3,5,6-tetramethylpyrazine, were synthesized under solvothermal conditions. In 1 and 7, polyanions link CuI-org. sheets to generate 3D (3,4)-connected frameworks. In 2, the polyanion bridges CuI-org. chains to yield a 3D (3,4,6)-connected framework. Both 3 and 4 exhibit 2D double layer structures. In 5, the Keggin polyanion bridges the CuI-Pyr chains to form an infinite 3D (3,4)-connected framework. In 6, CuI cations are bridged by the 2,3,5-Pyr and Keggin polyanions to generate a novel 2D (8,3) sheet. The roles of the pyrazine derivs. and the Keggin polyanions in the formation of the POM-based MOFs are discussed.

        A Solvothermally in Situ Generated Mixed-ligand Approach for NLO-Active Metal-Organic Framework Materials
        Wang, Yong-Tao; Fan, Hai-Hua; Wang, He-Zhou; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (12), 4148-4150CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The synthesis and crystal structures of two new NLO-active coordination polymers, [Zn(2-pc)(4-pc)] and [Cd(2-pc)(4-pc)(H2O)]·N2H4 (2-pc = 2-pyridinecarboxylate, 4-pc = 4-pyridinecarboxylate), bridged by in situ-generated mixed ligands under solvothermal treatment are described. The ligands are formed from solvolysis of 2-(2-pyridyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole in MeOH under solvothermal conditions with added Zn(OAc)2·6H2O or Cd(OAc)2·2H2O.

        11c
        Silver(I) Complexes of Fixed, Polytopic Bis(pyrazolyl)methane Ligands: Influence of Ligand Geometry on the Formation of Discrete Metallacycles and Coordination Polymers
        Reger, Daniel L.; Watson, Russell P.; Smith, Mark D.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (25), 10077-10087CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Reactions of the arene-linked bis(pyrazolyl)methane ligands m-bis[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene, (m-[CH(pz)2]2C6H4, Lm), p-bis[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene, (p-[CH(pz)2]2C6H4, Lp), and 1,3,5-tris[bis(1-pyrazolyl)methyl]benzene (1,3,5-[CH(pz)2]3C6H3, L3) with AgX salts (pz = 1-pyrazolyl; X = BF4- or PF6-) yield two types of mol. motifs depending on the arrangement of the ligating sites about the central arene ring. Reactions of the m-phenylene-linked Lm with AgBF4 and AgPF6 afford complexes consisting of discrete, metallacyclic dications:[Ag2(μ-Lm)2](BF4)2 (1) and [Ag2(μ-Lm)2](PF6)2 (2). When the p-phenylene-linked Lp is treated with AgBF4 and AgPF6, acyclic, cationic coordination polymers were obtained:{[Ag(μ-Lp)]BF4}∞ (3) and {[Ag(μ-Lp)]PF6}∞ (4). Reaction of the ligand L3, contg. three bis(pyrazolyl)methane units in a meta arrangement, with an equimolar amt. of AgBF4 again yields discrete metallacyclic dications in which one bis(pyrazolyl)methane unit on each ligand remains unbound: [Ag2(μ-L3)2](BF4)2 (5). Treatment of L3 with an excess of AgBF4 affords a polymer of metallacycles, {[Ag3(μ-L3)2](BF4)3}∞ (6), with one of the bis(pyrazolyl)methane units on each ligand bound to a silver cation bridging two metallacycles. The supramol. structures of the silver(I) complexes 1-6 are organized by noncovalent interactions, including weak hydrogen bonding, π-π, and anion-π interactions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVyhtrzO&md5=09726720ecd4fe10fdd9fd1946ceb844
        (d) Luo, F.; Che, Y. X.; Zheng, J. M. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 1066– 1071
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Trinuclear Cobalt Based Porous Coordination Polymers Showing Unique Topological and Magnetic Variety upon Different Dicarboxylate-like Ligands
        Luo, Feng; Che, Yun-xia; Zheng, Ji-min
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (2), 1066-1071CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        One-pot solvothermal self-assembly is employed to prep. Co3 based porous coordination polymers, viz. (1), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(i.p.)4]·H2O; (2), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bdc)4]·(DMF)2; (3), [H2NMe2]2[Co3(bpdc)4]·(CH3OH)2(DMF)1.5, where i.p., bdc, bpdc, and DMF are 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate, and N,N'-DMF, resp. Via different org. connectors such as i.p., bdc, and bpdc, such Co3 mol. building blocks (MBB), [Co3(CO2)8]2-, are assocd. together to give a tunable 8-connected topol. framework, viz. 42464 for 1, 36414576 for 2, and 36418536 for 3. Upon the geometry and the length of org. connectors, their corresponding porosity occupied by c counterions plus solvent mols. also can be tunable, for example, with the consideration of [H2NMe2]+ counterions, the solvent-accessible vol. is 460.2 Å3 for 1, equal to 23.9% of the cell vol., 3320.4 Å3 for 2, equal to 56.3% of the cell vol., 4107.2 Å3 for 3, equal to 50% of the cell vol. Notably, besides these outstanding features of tunable 8-connected topol. and porosity, their magnetic properties such as ferromagnetic behavior without magnetic ordering for 1, spin-canting and metamagnetic behavior with magnetic ordering for 2, as well as spin-canting, metamagnetic, and spin-glass behavior with magnetic ordering for 3 also can be tunable.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Three Topological Isomeric Coordination Polymer Networks from the Assembly of a Rigid Linear Spacer and a Square Planar Metal Node: Structures, Isomerism Control, and Solid-to-Solid Transformation
        Shin, Dong Mok; Lee, In Su; Cho, Dahye; Chung, Young Keun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (24), 7722-7724CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Assemblies of 1-methyl-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (mpe) and Co(NCS)2 afford three isomeric framework networks and different topol. features, [Co(mpe)2(NCS)2]∞, depending on the assembly conditions. Isomerism control and solid-to-solid transformation phenomena are obsd. among them.

        12b
        Novel supramolecular isomerism in coordination polymer synthesis from unsymmetrical bridging ligands: Solvent influence on the ligand placement orientation and final network structure
        Lee, In Su; Shin, Dong Mok; Chung, Young Keun
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2004), 10 (13), 3158-3165CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The assembly of Co(NCS)2 with 1-methyl-1'-(3-pyridyl)-2-(4-pyridyl)ethene (L1) exhibits a novel supramol. isomerism of [Co(L1)2(NCS)2]∞ (1 and 2) caused by different placement orientation of L1 around metal centers. The reaction in MeOH/H2O and EtOH/H2O resulted in a double chain structure of 1, and that in EtOH/CH3NO2 led to an open framework structure of 2. The reaction in MeOH/CH3NO2 solvent system concomitantly afforded 1 and 2. The assemblies of 1-methyl-1'-(3-pyridyl)-2-(4-pyrimidyl)ethene (L2) with Co(NCS)2 created the H2O-coordinated complexes of Co(L2)2(H2O)2(NCS)2 (3 and 4), an MeOH coordinated complex of Co(L2)2(H2O)2(NCS)2 (5), and an open framework coordination polymer of [Co(L1)2(NCS)2]∞ (6) depending on the reaction solvent system. Probably in the formation of 1, the solvent-coordinated intermediate species would be generated 1st and its trans coordination configuration should define the placement orientation of L1 in the resulting polymer of 1. However, it is presumed that the solvent-coordinated intermediate would not be produced during the formation of 2 due to the weaker coordination ability of EtOH and CH3NO2 mols. The open framework coordination polymers of 2 and 6 are converted in the solid state into the isomeric coordination polymer of 1 and H bonded network structure of 3, resp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        12c
        3D coordination polymers with nitrilotriacetic and 4,4'-bipyridyl mixed ligands: structural variation based on dinuclear or tetranuclear subunits assisted by Na-O and/or O-H...O interactions
        Lu Xing-Qiang; Jiang Ji-Jun; Chen Chun-Long; Kang Bei-Sheng; Su Cheng-Yong
        Inorganic chemistry (2005), 44 (13), 4515-21 ISSN:0020-1669.
        The reactions of Cu(II) with the mixed nitrilotriacetic acid (H3NTA) and 4,4'-bipyridyl (4,4'-bpy) ligands in different metal-to-ligand ratios in the presence of NaOH and NaClO4 afforded two complexes, Na3[Cu2(NTA)2(4,4'-bpy)]ClO4 x 5H2O (1) and [Cu2(NTA) (4,4'-bpy)2]ClO4 x 4H2O (2). The two complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, IR, XRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. 1 contains a basic doubly negatively charged [Cu2(NTA)2(4,4'-bpy)]2- dinuclear unit which was further assembled via multiple Na-O and O-H...O interactions into a three-dimensional (3D) pillared-layer structure. 2 features a two-dimensional (2D) undulated brick-wall architecture containing a basic doubly positively charged [Cu4(NTA)2(4,4'-bpy)2]2+ tetranuclear unit. The 2D network possesses large cavities hosting guest molecules and was further assembled via O-H...O hydrogen bonds into a 3D structure with several channels running in different directions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (d) Wu, S. T.; Long, L. S.; Huang, R. B.; Zheng, L. S. Cryst. Growth Des. 2007, 7, 1746– 1752

        12d
        pH-Dependent assembly of supramolecular architectures from zero- to two-dimensional networks
        Wu, Shu-Ting; Long, La-Sheng; Huang, Rong-Bin; Zheng, Lan-Sun
        Crystal Growth & Design (2007), 7 (9), 1746-1752CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Five Cu(II)/benzoate/4,4'-bipy complexes, namely, [Cu(H2O)(benzoate)2(4,4'-bipy)2](HOBz)2·(4,4'-bipy) (1), [Cu2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4'-bipy)3]·(H2O)9 (2), [Cu2(benzoate)4(4,4'-bipy)3] (3), [Cu3(H2O)4(benzoate)6(4,4'-bipy)4.5]·(4,4'-bipy)·(H2O)5 (4), and [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4'-bipy)2] (5) (4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine), were synthesized through hydrothermal reaction of Cu(II) nitrate, HOBz, and 4,4'-bipyridine under different pH conditions. The diverse product structures show the marked sensitivity of the structural chem. of the arom. carboxylate ligand to synthesis conditions. Complex 1, which exhibits a zero-dimensional (0D) structure of mononuclear Cu(II), is formed at pH = 5.5. At pH = 6.0, dimeric Cu(II) complexes of 2 and 3 are formed. Reaction at pH = 7 leads to a one-dimensional (1D) structure of 4. A further increase of the pH to 8.0 results in a two-dimensional (2D) structure of 5. Crystal data are monoclinic, space group P2/n, a 13.992(4), b 5.7153(14), c 31.126(8) Å, β 100.513(5)°, Z = 2 for 1, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a 30.283(5), b 15.139(2), c 14.457(2) Å, β 112.776(3)°, Z = 4 for 2, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a 5.8317(12), b 21.157(4), c 20.679(4) Å, β 94.343(3)°, Z = 2 for 3, triclinic, space group P‾1, a 14.016(3), b 18.492(4), c 19.353(4) Å, α 66.220(3), β 79.948(4), γ 88.390(3)°, Z = 2 for 4, and monoclinic, space group P21/c, a 5.6880(16), b 17.917(5), c 20.904(6) Å, β 92.959(5)°, Z = 2 for 5.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        (e) Sarma, R.; Kalita, D.; Baruah, J. B. Dalton Trans. 2009, 7428– 7436

        12e
        Solvent induced reactivity of 3,5-dimethylpyrazole towards zinc(II) carboxylates
        Sarma, Rupam; Kalita, Dipjyoti; Baruah, Jubaraj B.
        Dalton Transactions (2009), (36), 7428-7436CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The reactions of 3,5-dimethylpyrazole with zinc(II) acetate dihydrate and varieties of arom. carboxylic acids led to formation of mononuclear zinc complexes [Zn(HDMP)2(RCO2)2] (R = C6H5, p-CH3-C6H4, p-NO2-C6H4 etc., HDMP = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole) in MeOH, whereas the same reactants in DMF gave binuclear 3,5-dimethylpyrazolato bridged zinc carboxylate complexes contg. monodentate 3,5-dimethylpyrazole ligands with compn. [Zn2(μ-DMP)2(HDMP)2(RCO2)2]. The mononuclear complexes can be converted to the corresponding binuclear complexes by simply dissolving in DMF. The reaction of zinc(II) acetate dihydrate with p-nitrobenzoic acid and 3,5-dimethylpyrazole in different solvents gave solvated mononuclear complexes of the corresponding solvent. All these solvated complexes having the core [Zn(HDMP)2(p-NO2-C6H4CO2)2] contain two structurally independent mols. in the asym. unit (Z' = 2).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12f
        Synthesis, X-ray Structures, and Fluorescent Properties of Coordination Networks Constructed from 2-(2-Pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) Acetic Anion
        Wang, Zuo-Wei; Ji, Chang-Chun; Li, Jing; Guo, Zi-Jian; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zheng, He-Gen
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (1), 475-482CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Four new metal coordination polymers, [Cd(pybma)2]n (1), [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5·0.5H2O]n (2), [Co(pybma)(C2O4)0.5]n (3), and [Zn3(pybma)2(HBTC)2(H2O)4]n (4) [pybma = (2-(2-pyridinyl)benzimidazol-1-yl)acetate; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate], were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized by element analyses, IR spectroscopy, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses. Has a 1-dimensional (1D) chain structure, which contains two kinds of rings. Has a two-dimensional (2D) metal-org. framework and can be seen as the unity of two parallel double-stranded helixes, in which the helixes are bridged by oxalate ligands. Has a 2-dimensional framework built from 1-dimensional chains and ox bridges. Has 2-dimensional layer framework which is assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels. Polymers 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temp.; no fluorescent emission is obsd. in polymer 3.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsVShsb3P&md5=65a232f78f7db7d129f5ee9125d9ccee
        (g) Kanoo, P.; Gurunatha, K. L.; Maji, T. K. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 4147– 4156
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12g
        Temperature-Controlled Synthesis of Metal-Organic Coordination Polymers: Crystal Structure, Supramolecular Isomerism, and Porous Property
        Kanoo, Prakash; Gurunatha, K. L.; Maji, Tapas Kumar
        Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (9), 4147-4156CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Five new supramol. metal-org. coordination polymers (MOCPs), {[Ni(bipy) (H2O)4](2,6-nds)·4H2O} (1), {[Ni(bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)·2H2O} (2), {[Ni (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (3), {[Ni (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (4), {[Cu (bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)} (5) (bipy = 4,4'-bipyridyl; 2,6-nds = 2,6-naphthalenedisulfonate) have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Compds. 1 and 5 were synthesized at room temp. in H2O/EtOH medium, whereas 2-4 were isolated under hydrothermal conditions. Compds. 1-4 were synthesized maintaining the same stoichiometric ratio of metal and ligand under different reaction temps., and the different structures of the compds. indicate that the temp. plays a significant role in the construction of the coordination polymers. Structural characterization reveals that the one-dimensional [M(bipy)(H2O)4]2+ cationic chain is a basic building unit for all of the MOCPs, while 2,6-nds remains as a counteranion. In all cases, 2,6-nds counteranions interact with water and bipy mols. through strong hydrogen-bonding and π-π interactions to afford three-dimensional supramol. structures. Compds. 1-4 have the same building unit with different network superstructures and are related as supramol. isomers. Supramol. isomerism in 3 and 4 is very interesting since they have the same mol. formula, {[Ni(bipy)(H2O)4](2,6-nds)}, and are polymorphs. Compds. 4 and 5 are isomorphous. The thermogravimetric study suggests that the dehydrated compds. are stable up to 300°. Furthermore, sorption studies suggest that dehydrated compds. of 1 and 2 are permanently porous.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXpvV2nsb4%253D&md5=e7efb7696e37adb4c0d793bff194b0f0
      13. 13
        (a) Wang, Y.-L.; Yuan, D.-Q.; Bi, W.-H.; Li, X.; Li, X.-J.; Li, F.; Cao, R. Cryst. Growth Des. 2005, 5, 1849– 1855
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13a
        Syntheses and Characterizations of Two 3D Cobalt-Organic Frameworks from 2D Honeycomb Building Blocks
        Wang, Yu-Ling; Yuan, Da-Qiang; Bi, Wen-Hua; Li, Xing; Li, Xiao-Ju; Li, Feng; Cao, Rong
        Crystal Growth & Design (2005), 5 (5), 1849-1855CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        The hydrothermal reaction of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3IDC), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bipy) under different conditions affords two interesting metal-org. compds., {[Co3(IDC)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4]·2H2O}n (1) and {[Co3(IDC)2(4,4'-bipy)3]·6H2O·DMF}n (2), both of which have been structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric anal. Temp.-dependent magnetic susceptibility for 1 and 2 were also studied. The "all-chair" two-dimensional honeycomb networks, structurally analogous to CFx, were linked by the bridging 4,4'-bipy ligand in compd. 1 to give rise to a 2-fold interpenetrated 3D architecture. Compd. 2 features a three-dimensional open framework with hexagonal channels, generated from two-dimensional graphene-like layers pillared by 4,4'-bipy. The simplest cyclic motif of the 2D networks in 1 and 2 is a 24-membered hexagonal ring consisting of six Co(II) cations and six IDC3- trianions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXltlyrsr4%253D&md5=417c6505e947d4e9aae5824fe66bd5b4

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13b
        Two Stable 3D Metal-Organic Frameworks Constructed by Nanoscale Cages via Sharing the Single-Layer Walls
        Lu, Wen-Guan; Su, Cheng-Yong; Lu, Tong-Bu; Jiang, Long; Chen, Jia-Mei
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (1), 34-35CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Two stable 3-dimensional metal-org. frameworks, {Na4[Cd7(IDC)6].3bpy.7H2O}n (bipy - 4,4'-bipyridine) and {(Bu4N)K3[Cd7(IDC)6].6H2O}n, are constructed by the hydrothermal reactions of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O and imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (IDC3-) using bpy and Bu4NBr as templates. Both structures show the same frameworks, which are composed by the nanoscale cages via sharing the single-layer walls.

        13c
        Conversion of nonporous helical cadmium organic framework to a porous form
        Gu, Zhi-Gang; Cai, Yue-Peng; Fang, Hua-Cai; Zhou, Zheng-Yuan; Thallapally, Praveen K.; Tian, Jian; Liu, Jun; Exarhos, Gregory J.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2010), 46 (29), 5373-5375CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Two novel cadmium-org. frameworks contg. achiral helical nanotubular channels, [Cd(HImDC)(S)]n (S = imidazole (1) and pyridine (2), H3ImDC = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid), were synthesized and characterized using single crystal x-ray diffraction. Complex 1 converts to 2 upon refluxing 1 in pyridine soln. Both complexes have noticeable porosity and hydrogen uptake at medium pressure.

        13d
        A Family of Three-Dimensional Lanthanide-Zinc Heterometal-Organic Frameworks from 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylate and Oxalate
        Gu, Zhi-Gang; Fang, Hua-Cai; Yin, Pei-Yi; Tong, Long; Ying, Yin; Hu, She-Jun; Li, Wei-Shan; Cai, Yue-Peng
        Crystal Growth & Design (2011), 11 (6), 2220-2227CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A family of lanthanide-Zn coordination polymers with two different types of three-dimensional (3-D) frameworks based on 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid and oxalic acid, namely, {[Ln2(H2O)2Zn4(H2O)4(ImDC)4(ox)]·6H2O}n (Ln = La (1), Nd (2), Sm (3), Eu (4), and H3ImDC = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid, H2ox = oxalic acid) and {[Ln2(H2O)4Zn4(H2O)4(ImDC)4(ox)]·MeOH·2H2O}n (Ln = Eu (4'), Gd (5), Dy (6), Ho (7), Er (8), Yb (9), and Lu (10)), were successfully constructed under certain conditions and characterized by elemental anal., IR, thermogravimetric (TG), and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Compds. 1-4 (structure I) are isomorphous 3-dimensional coordination frameworks contg. two-dimensional (2-D) [Zn2(ImDC)2] layers and 1-dimensional (1-D) Ln2(μ2-O)2(ox) sine wave-like chains with 1-dimensional square channels, while 4'-10 coordination polymers (structure II) are also isomorphous and feature 3-dimensional pillar-layered coordination frameworks constructed from 2-dimensional Zn-carboxylate [Zn2(ImDC)2] layers and Ln2(ox) pillars with 1-dimensional flat channels. The structural variation from I to II with the Eu ion as a crit. point, in which two types of Eu complexes 4 and 4' can reversibly transform into each other, may be attributed to the lanthanide contraction effect. Meanwhile, the adsorption and photoluminescent properties of the compds. are also studied.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXlsVKks7o%253D&md5=31b94adaabd9b53f16d08a5bdcd50385
        (e) Feng, X.; Zhao, J. S.; Liu, B.; Wang, L. Y.; Ng, S.; Zhang, G.; Wang, J. G.; Shi, X. G.; Liu, Y. Y. Cryst. Growth Des. 2010, 10, 1399– 1408
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13e
        A Series of Lanthanide-Organic Frameworks Based on 2-Propyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate and Oxalate: Syntheses, Structures, Luminescence, and Magnetic Properties
        Feng, Xun; Zhao, Jianshe; Liu, Bin; Wang, Liya; Ng, Seikweng; Zhang, Gai; Wang, Jiange; Shi, Xinge; Liu, Yongyong
        Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (3), 1399-1408CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        A family of self-assembled lanthanide-org. coordination polymers with both rigid and flexible ligands formulated as {[Ln2(Hpimda)2(μ4-C2O4)·2H2O]·4H2O}n (Ln = Sm (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), Dy (4), Ho (5), Er (6), H3pimda = 2-propyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid) was synthesized from the reactions of H3pimda with trivalent lanthanide salts in the presence of oxalate as coligand. X-ray diffraction anal. reveals that these complexes are isomorphous and isostructural, and each forms a novel three-dimensional (3D) framework structure in which the metalloligands' two-dimensional (2D) networks were constructed from the lanthanide ion, 2-propyl-imidazole-dicarboxylate as well as oxalate ligands, and the oxalate further acts as a pillar to link the [Ln(Pimda)(oxo)] 2-dimensional grids to generate the 3-dimensional open frameworks, leaving 1-dimensional channels, which are occupied by H2O clusters displaying an intricate array. The luminescence emission spectra of the complexes vary depending on which lanthanide ion is present. Compds. 3, 4, and 5 exhibited weak but significant ferromagnetic couplings within the two adjacent magnetic centers bridged through oxalato, whereas dominant antiferromagnetic interaction was obsd. in the Er compd. 6.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Three new complexes synthesized from an imidazole-based dicarboxylate ligand containing hydroxymethyl group
        Zheng, Sheng-Run; Cai, Song-Liang; Fan, Jun; Xiao, Tian-Tian; Zhang, Wei-Guang
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2011), 14 (7), 1097-1101CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Three new complexes, [Cd(H2hmIDC)(bpy)]n (1), {[Co4(HIDC)4(bpy)4]·14H2O}n (2) and {[Co5(IDC)2(HIDC)2(phen)4(H2O)2]·12H2O}n (3) (H4hmIDC = 2-(hydroxymethyl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, H3IDC = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), were obtained under hydrothermal conditions by using H4hmIDC as initial reactant. Complex 1 is a zigzag chain contg. angular [Cd(bpy)]2+ node and H2hmIDC2- linker; compd. 2 is a discrete Co4 square; while 3 is a 1-dimensional chain based on Co4 square motifs similar to that in complex 2. In complex 1, the hydroxymethyl group of the H4hmIDC mol. remains integrated and acts as effective H bonding interaction site, while in complexes 2 and 3, all the hydroxymethyl groups are lost in situ. The hydroxymethyl groups undergo different reactions directed by metal ions.

        A 3D metal-org. framework, NH4[CdL] (H3L = 2-methylimidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid), was synthesized solvothermally and structurally characterized by single-crystal x-ray structure detn. This compd. crystallizes in the tetragonal system with the space group P42/nmc. The crystal structure presents a 3D framework and open channels, exhibiting guest-coordination sites at channel walls and strong fluorescent emission.

        2-Propyl-4,5-dicarboxylate-imidazole (H3PIDC) Based Cadmium(II) Coordination Compounds Stabilized by Supramolecular Interactions: From Mononuclear and Tetranuclear Oligomers to One-Dimensional (1D) Chain and Two-Dimensional (2D) Layer Polymers
        Deng, Ji-Hua; Zhong, Di-Chang; Luo, Xu-Zhong; Liu, Hui-Jin; Lu, Tong-Bu
        Crystal Growth & Design (2012), 12 (10), 4861-4869CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Six cadmium(II) coordination compds. with 2-propyl-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (H3PIDC), including two mononuclear complexes, [Cd(H2PIDC)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (1) and [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)4]·7H2O (2), two square tetranuclear complexes, [Cd4(HPIDC)4(H2O)8]·2H2O (3) and [Cd4(HPIDC)4(py)8]·10H2O (py = pyridine, 4), one one-dimensional chain polymer, [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)2]n·2nH2O (5), as well as one two-dimensional layer polymer, [Cd(H2PIDC)2]n (6), have been prepd. using solvent evapn. method and hydrothermal method. The results of single-crystal x-ray diffraction analyses indicate that, besides the common supramol. interactions such as hydrogen bond and π···π stacking, the hydrophobic interaction among the Pr groups in the H3PIDC ligands also contributes to the stabilities of 1-6. The study of substance transformation for 3 reveals that the coordinated H2O mols. in 3 can be well replaced by pyridine mols., indirectly giving 4. The results of photoluminescent measurements illustrate upon photoexcitation that 3-6 can emit fluorescence in the wavelength range of 451-473 nm in the solid state.

        14c
        Ligand-directed and solvent-controlled assembly of six novel functional supramolecular metal-organic frameworks
        Zhao, Xia; Ye, Xiao-Ping; Chang, Li-Mei; Chen, Chu-Jun; Gao, Jin-Ying; Yue, Shan-Tang; Cai, Yue-Peng
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2012), 25 (), 96-102CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Six novel functional metal-org. frameworks, namely, [CdCl(IP)(Hpydc)(H2O)]·2H2O (1), [Cd(IP)(H2imdc)]Cl (2), [Cd(IP)2(H2O)2](1,5-nds)·2H2O (3), [Co(IP)(H2O)4](1,5-nds)·H2O (4), [Zn(IP)(μ2-SO4)(H2O)]·H2O (5), [Zn(IP)(SO4)(H2O)3] (6) (IP = 1-H-imidazo[4,5-f][1,10]-phenanthroline, H2pydc = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, H3imdc = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, 1,5-nds = 1,5-naphthalenedisulfonate), were synthesized by controlling auxiliary ligands, metal centers and solvents. In compd. 1, Cd(II) is chelated by IP and Hpydc ligands, forming 0-dimensional → 3-dimensional supramol. structure. Compd. 2 is a 1-dimensional chain with repeated [Cd(IP)]2+ units connected by H2imdc ligands. With different metal centers, 3 and 4 possess different crystal structures. With solvents regulated, compds. 5 and 6 exhibit distinct structures. In 5, sulfate anions show μ2-bridging mode, which gave 1-dimensional chain. In compd. 6, only one O atom from sulfate anion coordinates to the metal center, resulting in discrete repeated units. The luminescent properties of 1, 2, 3, 5, 6 and thermal stabilities of all compds. were measured.

        Secondary ligand-directed assembly of metal-organic coordination polymers based on a 2-(pyridin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid ligand: Syntheses, structures and photoluminescent properties
        Yuan, Gang; Shao, Kui-Zhan; Du, Dong-Ying; Wang, Xin-Long; Su, Zhong-Min; Ma, Jian-Fang
        CrystEngComm (2012), 14 (5), 1865-1873CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Seven mixed-ligand coordination polymers, namely [Cd2(HPIDC)2(bipy)]n (1), {[Cd3(HPIDC)2(btc)(H2O)4]·H2O}n (2), {[Cd2(HPIDC)2(bdc)1/2(H2O)Cl]·H2O}n (3), {[Cd2(PIDC)(Ac)(H2O)]·H2O}n (4), [Zn2(HPIDC)(ox)(H2O)2]n (5), {[Eu(HPIDC)(ox)1/2H2O]·2H2O}n (6), and {[Tb(HPIDC)(ox)1/2H2O]·2H2O}n (7) (H3PIDC = 2-(pyridin-4-yl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine, H4btc = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid, H2bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, H2ox = oxalic acid) were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Their structures were detd. by single crystal x-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). Complexes 1 and 2 display a two-dimensional (2D) layer formed by the inter-linking helixes and ligands connecting di-metal units, resp. Both 3 and 4 assume a 3D covalent framework built up from mixed ligands linking two types of rod-shaped SBUs with trinodal (3,4)-connected and (3,4,5)-connected nets. Complexes 5-7 feature a 3D network constructed from HPIDC2- and ox2- anions bridging metal centers exhibiting the CdSO4 and α-Po nets, resp. Moreover, the photoluminescent properties of 1-7 were studied in the solid state at room temp.

        14g
        A combined experimental and DFT/TDDFT investigation of structural, electronic, and pH-induced tuning of photophysical and redox properties of osmium(ii) mixed-chelates derived from imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid and 2,2'-bipyridine
        Das, Shyamal; Saha, Debasish; Mardanya, Sourav; Baitalik, Sujoy
        Dalton Transactions (2012), 41 (39), 12296-12310CODEN: DTARAF; ISSN:1477-9226. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Exptl. results coupled with computational studies were used to study the structural and electronic properties of mixed-ligand monometallic Os(ii) complexes [(bipy)2Os(H2Imdc)]+ (1+), the N-H deprotonated form [(bipy)2Os(HImdc)] (1), and the COOH deprotonated form [(bipy)2Os(Imdc)]- (1-), where H3Imdc = imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid and bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine. The x-ray crystal structures of [(bipy)2Os(H2Imdc)]+ (1+) and [(bipy)2Os(HImdc)] (1) were detd., which showed that compd. 1+ crystallizes in a monoclinic form with the space group P2(1)/c, while 1 is obtained in a triclinic form with the space group P1. The optimized geometrical parameters for the complexes computed both in the gas phase and in soln. are reported and compared with the available x-ray data. The influence of pH on the photophys. and redox properties of the complexes was thoroughly studied. As compared to protonated complex (1+), which undergoes reversible oxidn. at 0.50 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) in MeCN, the redox potential of the fully deprotonated complex (1-) is shifted to a much lower value, 0.16 V The proton-coupled redox activity of 1+ was studied over the pH range 2-12 in an MeCN-H2O (3 : 2) medium. From the pH vs. E1/2 profile, the equil. consts. of the complex species in the protonated/deprotonated forms and the metal ion in +2/+3 oxidn. states were detd. Using these values the bond dissocn. free energies for the imidazole N-H and COOH bonds also were estd. The pKa values for 1+ in the +2 state also were detd. spectrophotometrically. Substantial red-shifts in the MLCT bands and the large shift in the E1/2 value to a less pos. potential that occur on deprotonation are energetically correlated. D. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) studies provide insight into the nature of the ground and excited states, with resulting detailed assignments of the orbitals involved in the absorption and emission transitions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtlKksL7I&md5=88e6e8b7c2346f2bbc8b53365f56c771
      15. 15
        (a) Wang, W.-Y.; Niu, X.-L.; Gao, Y.-C.; Zhu, Y.-Y.; Li, G.; Lu, H.-J.; Tang, M.-S. Cryst. Growth Des. 2010, 10, 4050– 4059

        15a
        Two Chiral and One Achiral 3-D Coordination Polymers Constructed by 2-Phenyl Imidazole Dicarboxylate
        Wang, Wenyue; Niu, Xiling; Gao, Yongchao; Zhu, Yanyan; Li, Gang; Lu, Huijie; Tang, Mingsheng
        Crystal Growth & Design (2010), 10 (9), 4050-4059CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Two chiral three-dimensional (3-D) coordination polymers, [Cd4(μ3-HPhIDC)2(μ4-HPhIDC)2(H2O)] (1) and [Mn1.5(μ3-PhIDC)(H2O)3] (2), and one achiral 3-dimensional coordination polymer, [Mn(μ3-HPhIDC)(H2O)]2 (3), were synthesized by hydro(solvo)thermal reaction, employing 2-phenyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3PhIDC) as org. ligand, and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, elemental analyses, and IR spectra. Polymer 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic chiral space group P2(1)2(1)2(1) and exhibits a 3-dimensional framework, in which two-dimensional (2-D) layers are composed of right-handed helixes along the b-axis and are further pillared by μ4-HPhIDC2- linkages. Polymer 2 crystallizes in trigonal chiral space group R‾3 and presents a novel 3-dimensional structure, which is generated from 2-dimensional honeycomb-like layers, contg. similar right-handed helical chains along the a or b axes, resp. Polymer 3 also has a 3-dimensional architecture and is composed of novel 2-dimensional stair-like layers in the bc plane. The theor. prediction of the Ph substituent effect of the H3PhIDC ligand has 1st been presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXpsVKrsLc%253D&md5=c7e5e061575690fa8852502bb9760622

        15b
        2-phenyl-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate-based metal-organic frameworks assembled under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions
        Wang, Wen-Yue; Yang, Ze-Li; Wang, Cheng-Jie; Lu, Hui-Jie; Zang, Shuang-Quan; Li, Gang
        CrystEngComm (2011), 13 (15), 4895-4902CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Four metal-org. frameworks, namely, [Cd2(μ2-HPhIDC)2(phen)2] (H3PhIDC = 2-phenyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) (I), [Cd2(μ2-HPhIDC)2(2,2'-bipy)2] (2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine) (II), [Pb3(μ4-PhIDC)2(H2O)] (III), and [Sr(μ2-H2PhIDC)2(H2O)4].2H2O (IV) were synthesized under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, and characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy and single crystal x-ray diffraction. Both I and II are 1D infinite chains. Compd. III features a 2D framework, in which Pb2+ ions are bridged by μ4-PhIDC3- ligands. Compd. IV possesses a 3D framework with a uninodal 4-connected net. The thermal and photoluminescence properties of polymers I-IV were investigated as well.

        An unprecedented 1-D mixed-valence Cu(II)/Cu(I) metal-organic framework bearing 2-phenyl imidazole dicarboxylates
        Zhu, Yu; Wang, Wen-yue; Guo, Meng-wei; Li, Gang; Lu, Hui-jie
        Inorganic Chemistry Communications (2011), 14 (9), 1432-1435CODEN: ICCOFP; ISSN:1387-7003. (Elsevier B.V.)
        An unprecedented mixed-valence Cu(I)/Cu(II) metal-org. framework {[Cu2(HPhIDC)(OH)]·H2O}n (H3PhIDC = 2-phenyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid) (1) was solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental anal., IR spectroscopy, XPS spectrum and single crystal x-ray diffraction anal. In 1, each Cu(I) ion is two-coordinated by imidazole and OH-units. The HPhIDC2-ligands connect Cu(II) ions leading to a 1-dimensional chain structure. The thermal properties of 1 are reported.

        15d
        Four Novel Frameworks Built by Imidazole-Based Dicarboxylate Ligands: Hydro(Solvo)thermal Synthesis, Crystal Structures, and Properties
        Zhang, Fuwei; Li, Zifeng; Ge, Tiezhu; Yao, Hongchang; Li, Gang; Lu, Huijie; Zhu, Yanyan
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 49 (8), 3776-3788CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Four novel complexes, {[Ni4(HEIDC)4(H2O)8]·2H2O} (1), {[Mn(HEIDC)(4,4'-bipy)0.5(H2O)]·H2O}n (2), [Mn6(EIDC)4(py)4(H2O)4]n (3), and {[Cd2(EIDC)(H2EIDC)(4,4'-bipy)1.5]·H2O}n (4) (H3EIDC = 2-ethyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, and py = pyridine) were hydro(solvo)thermally synthesized by fine control over synthetic conditions, such as solvent and pH value, and structurally characterized. It is shown through single-crystal x-ray diffractions that the ligands H3EIDC can be either singly, doubly, or triply deprotonated and can coordinate to Ni(II), Mn(II) or Cd(II) ions in μ2 or μ3 modes. Compd. 1 is a zero-dimensional (0D) sym. tetranuclear mol. square. Compd. 2 exhibits a two-dimensional (2D) sheet, in which alternate left- and right-handed helical chains are bridged by 4,4'-bipy linkages. Compd. 3 assumes a 2-dimensional honeycomb-like sheet built up from μ3-EIDC3- and Mn(II) atoms. Compd. 4 possesses a novel three-dimensional (3D) structure constructed from 2-dimensional layer motifs joined by μ2-HEIDC2- and 4,4'-bipy bridges. The thermal properties of complexes 1-4 were detd. as well. Also, there exists antiferromagnetic coupling between the Ni(II) or Mn(II) ions in 1 or 2(3); the best fittings to the exptl. magnetic susceptibilities gave J = -10.83 cm-1 and g = 2.19 for 1, and J = -0.025 cm-1, zJ' = -0.02 cm-1 and g = 2.0 for 2.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Four cadmium(II) polymeric frameworks constructed by 2-methyl or 2-ethyl imidazole dicarboxylates
        Li, Zi-Feng; Luo, Xiao-Bo; Gao, Yong-Chao; Lu, Hui-Jie; Li, Gang
        Inorganica Chimica Acta (2012), 384 (), 352-362CODEN: ICHAA3; ISSN:0020-1693. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Four polymeric frameworks, {[Cd(HMIDC)(phen)].H2O}n (I), {[Cd4(HMIDC)4].8H2O}n (II), [Cd(HMIDC)(2,2'-bipy)]n (III), and {[Cd(HEIDC)(2,2'-bipy)]2}n (IV) (H3MIDC = 2-methyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, H3EIDC = 2-ethyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, 2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine) were hydro(solvo)thermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. II shows a 3D structure constructed from 2D layer motifs joined by μ2-HMIDC2- or μ3-MIDC3- ligands. The thermal and solid-state photoluminescence properties of complexes I-IV were detd. as well.

        Guo, Mengwei; Chen, Nan; Yue, Zhifang; Zhang, Yu; Li, Gang
        CrystEngComm (2012), 14 (15), 4955-4958CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Solvothermal reactions of nitrate salts with the promising multifunctional org. ligand, 2-(2-naphthyl)-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid (H3NIDC), lead to two new polymers, [Sr(μ5-HNIDC)(H2O)]n (1) and [Cd(μ3-HNIDC)(CH3CH2OH)]n (2). Polymer 1 exhibits a sheet structure contg. infinite distorted hexagonal rings. Polymer 2 presents an interesting 3D open architecture possessing infinite one-dimensional channels. The thermal analyses and solid-state photoluminescence properties of polymers 1 and 2 were studied as well.

        Design and construction of six metal-organic frameworks with 2-p-methoxyphenyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate
        Cao, Xinjiang; Zhang, Jun; Wang, Chengjie; Zhu, Yanyan; Li, Gang
        CrystEngComm (2012), 14 (13), 4357-4368CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Six novel transition-metal-org. frameworks, [Cu(μ2-HMOPhIDC)(H2O)]n (H3MOPhIDC = 2-p-methoxyphenyl-1H-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylic acid) (1), [Zn(μ2-HMOPhIDC)(2,2'-bipy)]n (2,2'-bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine) (2), [Co(μ2-HMOPhIDC)(2,2'-bipy)]n (3), [Co(μ2-HMOPhIDC)(phen)]n (phen = 1,10-phenanthroline) (4), [Cd1.5(μ2-H2MOPhIDC)(μ3-HMOPhIDC)(H2O)]n (5) and {[Co1.5(μ2-H2MOPhIDC)(μ3-HMOPhIDC)(py)]·2H2O}n (py = pyridine) (6) were successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, and characterized by elemental analyses, IR and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. The org. ligand H3MOPhIDC can be singly deprotonated or doubly deprotonated, and coordinate to metal ions in various modes. Polymers 1-4 display an infinite polymeric chain structure connected by μ2-HMOPhIDC2- ligands, but show different crystal packing fashions. Polymers 5 and 6 exhibit two-dimensional sheet structures built from double-stranded chains. The thermal properties of polymers 1-6 and luminescence properties of 2 and 5 were detd. Also, the magnetic properties of polymers 1, 3, 4 and 6 were studied.
